bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

body.div1:
UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON Northern Division
In re George Hawkins Application for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
NO. 1047. ORDER.
And now on this 7th day of November, 1902, Charles B. Hopkins, United States Marshal for the District of Washington, having in obedience to the Writ of Habeas Corpus heretofore granted produced in open court the said George Hawkins, and endorsed upon said writ his return, and the said Hawkins being personally present, and also represented by his counsel, James E. Fenton, and John B. Allen, and Melvin Grigsby, United States District Attorney for the Second Division of the District of Alaska, appearing specially in behalf of the government of the United States, and the court having heard and considered the petition, the return thereto, the arguments of counsel, and being now sufficiently advised in the premises, doth now decide, order and adjudge as follows:
THE COURT:
This petitioner is actually within the territorial limits of the jurisdiction of this court, for he is actually within the boundaries of the District of Washington. He is, therefore, under the protection of the Constitution of the United States, which declares that no person shall be deprived of his liberty without due process of law, and this court is charged with the responsibility of protecting him in that right. There is no question in my mind but what the court has jursidiction to act upon this petition. I
do not think I should have any delicacy in doing what seems to be right in the matter out of regard for the order which Judge Moore has made. As Judge of that court he made a ruling in accordance with the provisions of the local law of Alaska, but it is a fact nevertheless that the court in Alaska did not have jurisdiction of the person of the defendant; that is, actual physical jurisdiction. Its jurisdiction was only theortecial, by reason of his having been in that jurisdiction and having been the subject of judicial proceedings. Now, the inquiry to be made is whether this petitioner is being restrained of his liberty without due process of law He is restrained of his liberty. By what lawful authority? What is the process? Where is the writ? It is not permissible for the Warden of the Penitentiary on McNeil's Island to detain and incarcerate within the walls of that insitution any person without judicial process, he must have a judicial writ. According to the petition and the return, there is no writ except the warrant of commitment, which is in legal effect annulled by the decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversing the judgment of conviction. If there is anything else which takes the place of the writ and has the force of a writ, it must be the mandate of the Circuit Court of Appeals. If that does not take hold of the person of the petitioner and commit him for trial at Nome, Alaska, then there is nothing. Now, assuming that there may be such a thing as a legal commitment without an actual writ of mandate of the appellate court, there has been a failure on the part of the government, to do its duty in taking the petitioner out of the Penitentiary in which he was being held to the place of trial, during the season of 1902, when navigation was open, and when it might have been done. There was time between the date of the decision at San Francisco and the closing of navigation for the government to have done that. If the mandate of that court affects the petitioner at all, it affects a man in custody and powerless to remove himself to Alaska.
It is to be regarded as a command to a ministerial officer charged with the execution of its process to take him out of the Penitentiary and back to Alaska. That has not been done, and that places the matter before the court in this light, that this petitioner is being unlawfully deprived of his liberty in violation of the Constitution of the United States, because it is without judicial process. Now what should be done with him? The District Attorney denies the authority of thsi court to admit the prisoner to bail. But if this court has no right to hold him to bail and release him upon his giving bail, the duty of the court would be to give him his liberty absolutely. I am inclined, however, to risk any question there may be of assuming authority, to admit him to bail.
It is the order of this court that the application of the petitioner for a writ of habeas corpus be and it is hereby granted, and it is further ordered upon the petition, that the petitioner be admitted to bail in the sum of $3,000.00, conditioned for his appearance at Nome, Alaska, at the date set for his trial, there to remain, and not depart without leave, until the termination of the prosecution against him under the indictment which ahs been found against him. And upon his showing of the peculiar circumstances of his case it is further ordered by this court that he be admitted to bail in the amount specified upon his own personal recognizance.
ALLEN:-
If it please the court, I would like to make an inquiry. I want to know whether he could not go and surrender himself back to the place--because he is poor, and might possibly have some trouble in paying his fare up there,-- if it would not be satisfactory, if in ample time, whether he could surrender himself and notify the authorities so that he could be taken back up there, if he should happen to be in a position where he could not pay his fare back.
DISTRICT ATTY:
I will arrange that the defendant may be taken to Nome at such time as may be required.
PRISONER called to the bar.
THE COURT:
You, George Hawkins, acknowledge yourself to be indebted and owe the United States of America the sum of $3000.00, the same to be collected by levy upon your goods, chattels, lands and tenements, wheresoever situated, conditioned, nevertheless, that if you shall appear at Nome, in the Second Judicial District of Alaska, for trial upon the indictment there pending against you on the day fixed by the order of that court for trial and from day to day thereafter and from term to term of the court, and not depart without leave, the this obligation is to be void, otherwise to be in full force and virtue. Do you so acknowledge?
PRISONER: Yes, sir.
THE COURT: The prisoner is now released from custody.
C. H. Hanford Judge
TX
No. 1047.
Form No. 599.
G.O.B. 7-385
IN THE Circuit COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON.
In re George Hawkins. Application for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
ORDER.
Filed Jan 2, 1903 A Reeves Ayres, Clerk,
By A. N. Moore, Deputy.
